report_title: Industry Report on Corn, Wheat and Soybean Wholesalers
executive_summary: The image shows employment had a CAGR of 1.34% from 2004-2023 but is projected to decline at -5.46% from 2023-2029. Wages had a CAGR of 0.22% from 2004-2023 and are projected to decrease by -6.04% from 2023-2029. The corn, wheat and soybean wholesale industry was resilient during COVID-19 as food is a necessity. However, supply and demand imbalances caused agricultural prices to surge then plummet, impacting revenue. Government biofuel subsidies provide a lifeline.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wholesalers aren't primarily affected by shifting consumer demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Crops serve consumers long-term so preferences don't reduce revenue much short-term. Wheat, corn and soybeans remain dietary staples. COVID-19 only modestly reduced revenue as food is a necessity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The pandemic recovery has caused agricultural prices to surge
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Some markets declined more during the pandemic. Wholesalers cut back capacity. When restrictions eased, surging demand outpaced supply, causing crop price spikes. Wholesalers could pass on higher costs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The war in Ukraine restricts the wheat supply
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As a major wheat producer, the war disrupted the global wheat market. But US wheat farming was less impacted by reduced wheat imports.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Easing supply chains threaten revenue from corn, wheat and soybean wholesalers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2023, as supply matched demand, crop prices dropped significantly, reducing wholesaler revenue tied to prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The increased use of biofuels gives the industry a consistent lifeline
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Laws like the Renewable Fuel Standard require biofuel use, boosting demand for corn and soybean oils used in biofuels, benefiting wholesalers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Corn prices tank from more land usage and expensive fertilizer
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Corn prices will fall as farm production matches pandemic demand surge. Rising fertilizer costs will also reduce corn demand from farmers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Meager biofuel usage hinders soybean markets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Soybeans can substitute corn, but stalled biofuel use and easing supply chains will still cause soybean price declines.
More diverse diets will reduce wheat demand. Reviving exports will also contribute to declining wheat prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased innovation will try to provide a lifeline for wholesalers in the face of dropping crop prices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Wholesalers will computerize inventory control and adopt supply chain networks to increase efficiency and sales amid lower crop prices.

industry_definition: Operators purchase and distribute grains such as corn, rice, wheat, dry beans, soybeans and other inedible beans to food processors, manufacturers, animal feed producers, exporters and other buyers. Includes grain elevator operators for bulk wholesale but excludes storage-only elevators and seed wholesalers.
key_trends: Revenue volatility due to pandemic and agricultural price fluctuations, with biofuel subsidies boosting corn and soybean demand.
Outlook period looks bleak with plunging crop prices causing revenue decline, though wholesalers aim to innovate.
Regulations relate to grain inspection, processing methods and warehousing, impacting wholesalers downstream of farmers.
Assistance from government laws and private organizations like National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors.
Wheat prices to fall significantly due to easing supply chains and rising fertilizer costs, with substitutes like soybeans becoming more attractive.
Retail markets faced revenue surge during COVID recovery as restrictions lifted and consumers spent more.
The Plains region is largest producer, so wholesalers locate there. Some presence in high-population Mid-Atlantic region.
Major wholesalers operate across farming and food processing to improve efficiency, limiting consolidation.
Top firms comprise 30% of revenue, indicating moderate consolidation. Largest firm Archer-Daniels-Midland at 13.1% share.
Major firm CHS Inc. financially supports agricultural technology initiatives to improve long-term yields and profit.

market_segmentation.segment_description: While corn, wheat and soybean wholesalers sell to a variety of markets, such as food processors and other farmers, more than half of their revenue comes from selling their products to other wholesalers, who proceed to transfer these goods to other businesses.

market_segmentation.segment: Farmers for use in farm production
market_segmentation.segment_description: Farmers also buy from corn wholesalers so they can feed their animals.
Corn, wheat and soybeans are purchased from manufacturers of products, such as cookies, pasta and crackers.
Markets for wholesalers in the 'other' category include spending from households directly, governmental bodies and restaurants.
Wholesalers receive a small portion of their funds from retailers, who sell corn, wheat and soybeans directly to consumers.

products_and_services.product_description: As more young people adopt meatless diets, types of seeds (e.g. walnuts and almonds) and beans have become more popular, as they provide a great source of protein.

Sorghum is an ancient grain that represents less than 2.0% of revenue for wholesalers. The grain is gluten-free, and this type of diet has become more popular in the United States, so the selling of Sorghum has risen during the current period and will continue to increase during the outlook period.

tier_1_suppliers: Truck & Bus Manufacturing in the US
Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Wheat, Barley & Sorghum Farming in the US
tier_1_buyers: Animal Food Production in the US
Cookie, Cracker & Pasta Production in the US
Frozen Food Production in the US
tier_2_buyers: Animal Food Production in the US
Cookie, Cracker & Pasta Production in the US
Frozen Food Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: CORN SELLING IS UNDER THREAT FROM SOARING FERTILIZER COSTS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The price of corn is predictive of how much corn wholesalers will sell.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: SOYBEANS BENEFIT BY BEING A CORN SUBSTITUTE
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Similar to corn, soybean prices are a strong indicator of soybean sales by wholesalers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: WHEAT MARKETS RISE AND FALL WITH THEIR PRICES
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Wheat sales performed well during the current period as, wheat prices soared in 2021 and 2022.
Beer Markets Influence the Selling of Oats and Barley.

business_locations.location_description: The Plains' states have significantly fertile land, which is used to grow large quantities of wheat, corn and soybeans.
The Great Lakes region contains states, such as Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, which have large swaths of rural areas that are used for farming.
While this region contains a smaller share of wholesalers compared with its share of the US population, some crops produced in these states are important for many companies.
The Mid-Atlantic region has a very small percentage of wholesalers compared with its proportion of the country's population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The 1946 law enables the Secretary of Agriculture to determine the methods for processing, packaging and marketing of grains.
Originally based on the Grains Standards Act of 1976, this 2020 act requires registration.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Uniform Grain and Rice Storage Agreement
regulations_points.regulation_description: This 1995 agreement forces grain and rice warehouse operators to pay fees to the Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC).
Antitrust legislation often isn't enacted on wholesalers and farmers, as these industries are highly competitive.
As COVID-19 rocked the country, states and localities forced workers to socially distance themselves and wear masks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage, which increases barriers to entry.
The industry has high revenue volatility, which increases barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Major corn, wheat and soybean wholesalers tend to operate in other industries to improve efficiency.
Most companies operate in a specific area, increasing the number of operators and industry fragmentation.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Major companies that wholesale operate in farming and food processing, which keeps consolidation low.
Most wholesalers want to be located near specific farmers and buyers, keeping the industry fragmented.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2023, purchase costs will comprise 90.6% of revenue.
Miscellaneous costs will make up 2.4% of revenue in 2023.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are a small cost for wholesalers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages will comprise 1.1% of revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Wholesaling relies heavily on machinery that's automatic.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Key Agricultural Products' Prices Create Major Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The prices of these crops are a major determinant for the industry's success.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Unpredictable Weather Makes Crop Levels Uncertain
volatility_points.volatility_description: Extreme weather can lead to an unexpected drop in crop yields.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Changes in prices and demand affect the wholesaling industry.

FAQs.question: Antitrust Laws
FAQs.answer: Antitrust legislation often isn't enacted on wholesalers and farmers, as these industries are highly competitive.

FAQs.question: Pandemic-Era Rules
FAQs.answer: As COVID-19 rocked the country, states and localities forced workers to socially distance themselves and wear masks.

FAQs.question: Industry Assistance
FAQs.answer: Founded in 1946, the NAW represents more than 35,000 wholesalers, including those that transfer corn, wheat and soybeans.
